message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs suggest a viral conjunctivitis. Topical antibiotics and glucocorticoids may cause unnecessary side effects and can prolong the illness. Warm compresses can help relieve the symptoms and do not have side effects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest viral conjunctivitis, which is self-limiting and doesn't require medication. Warm compresses can help relieve symptoms. Topical erythromycin ointment is used for bacterial conjunctivitis, which is less likely given the absence of adhesion of eyelids. Oral azithromycin is also used for bacterial conjunctivitis and is not necessary in this case. Topical glucocorticoids can have side effects and are not recommended unless specifically prescribed by an ophthalmologist.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest viral conjunctivitis, which is usually self-limited and requires only symptomatic relief. Warm compresses can help relieve the discomfort caused by the inflammation. Antibiotics are not necessary since it is a viral infection. Topical glucocorticoids are not recommended as they can actually prolong the course of the infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest viral conjunctivitis, given the redness, irritation, mucous discharge without adhesion, sore throat, and enlarged tender lymph node. Treatment is usually supportive, with warm compresses to provide relief. Topical antibiotics and glucocorticoids are not recommended for viral conjunctivitis. Oral antibiotics may be considered for bacterial conjunctivitis, but it is not the likely diagnosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a viral conjunctivitis, which is typically self-limited and treated with supportive care. Warm compresses can help relieve the symptoms and promote healing. Topical erythromycin ointment is usually used for bacterial causes of conjunctivitis. Oral azithromycin can be used for chlamydial conjunctivitis. Topical glucocorticoids are not recommended for viral conjunctivitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest viral conjunctivitis, which is usually self-limiting and does not require medication. Warm compresses can provide symptomatic relief. Topical antibiotics are not effective against viral infections, and topical glucocorticoids may increase the risk of viral replication. Oral azithromycin is not necessary for self-limited viral conjunctivitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms such as eye redness, irritation, watery mucous discharge, and crusting in the mornings suggest viral conjunctivitis. The presence of a sore throat and enlarged tender preauricular lymph node indicate a possible viral etiology. Warm compresses are the most appropriate treatment as it helps alleviate symptoms and aids in clearing discharge. Antibiotics are not recommended for viral conjunctivitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms match viral conjunctivitis, which is self-limiting and resolves within 1-2 weeks. Treatment is mainly supportive and includes warm compresses for comfort. Topical antibiotics or glucocorticoids are not appropriate as they can have adverse effects or worsen the condition. Oral antibiotics are also unnecessary as viral infections do not respond to antibiotics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of viral conjunctivitis, which is usually self-limited and treated with supportive care such as warm compresses. Topical antibiotics are not recommended as they can increase resistance and may prolong symptoms. Topical glucocorticoids are also not recommended as they can delay viral clearance and increase the risk of secondary infections. Azithromycin may be considered in severe cases or in cases with concurrent bacterial infection, but supportive care is the initial recommended treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest viral conjunctivitis, which is usually self-limiting and treated with warm compresses to provide symptomatic relief. Topical antibiotics or glucocorticoids are not indicated for viral conjunctivitis. Only in severe cases with bacterial co-infection, topical antibiotics may be used.
